TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: Hypoxia
   24 Hour Events:
 INDWELLING PORT (PORTACATH) - START [**2130-12-10**] 11:30 AM
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2130-12-10**] 05:44 PM
 NASAL SWAB - At [**2130-12-10**] 06:01 PM
 EKG - At [**2130-12-10**] 06:33 PM
 ARTERIAL LINE - START [**2130-12-10**] 09:04 PM
 EKG - At [**2130-12-10**] 10:00 PM
   Was brought back to ICU for new-onset hypoxia.  Was found to have
   diffuse ground-glass appearance to lungs on CT scan.  Hypoxia worsened
   and he was intubated.  .   Had a bronchoscopy which was unrevealing for
   cause other than small amount of bleeding.  He became hypotensive and
   tachycardic to 160.  Stayed in sinus.  Was treated with fluid boluses
   until started to develop pulmonary edema.  Lopressor 15 was given,
   which helped bring heart rate down.  Levophed was started for MAP of
   58, he did not respond so phenylephrine and vasopressin started.  Urine
   output has dropped off, but his resp picture is improving.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Piperacillin - [**2130-12-9**] 02:00 AM
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2130-12-9**] 10:11 AM

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:22.0/42.7/2.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:56//0.04, ALT / AST:16/34, Alk Phos / T Bili:74/1.6, Amylase
   / Lipase:/9, Differential-Neuts:88.1 %, Lymph:7.3 %, Mono:3.4 %,
   Eos:1.0 %, Lactic Acid:2.4 mmol/L, Albumin:2.4 g/dL, LDH:267 IU/L,
   Ca++:7.1 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL  On transfer: Labs
   notable for WBC of 17, lactate of 6.0.
   CTA
   IMPRESSION:
   1. No evidence of pulmonary embolus.
   2. Interval development of widespread patchy ground-glass opacities.
   Given
   the rapidity of onset, this most likely represents an atypical
   infection or
   drug reaction.
   3. Increased mass-like thickening of the distal esophagus compared to
   the
   [**Month (only) 319**] PET scan, with minimal interval increase in size of prevascular
   lymph
   nodes and gastroesophageal lymph nodes. There is ascites and a nodular
   appearance of the mesentery, which may be due to worsening hepatic
   failure,
   but is also concerning for carcinomatosis.
   4. Stable biilateral pleural effusions.
   BAL, Ascites, and Sputum: NTD
   Urine: small amount of probable enterococcus
   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially thought to be PE and patient
   was started on Heparin despite guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent
   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for
   hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Continue broadened coverage to Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime (expanded GI and
   GNR coverage) as well as Vanc, Zosyn, Azithro
   - Q2 MDIs PRN
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves
   .
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs
   they may have
   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, start tube feeds
   #Prophy: pneumoboots, heparin TID, type and screen
   #Code status: Full Code
   #Communication: Patient; brother is health care proxy
   #Dispo: pending clinical stability
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxia. The patient's condition has worsened, and he is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 7.2-13.0 K/uL
* Hct: 27-33.9%
* Plt: 49-71 K/uL
* Cr: 0.7-0.9 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01-0.04 ng/mL
* TCO2: 20-23 mmHg
* Glucose: 104-246 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 22.0/42.7/2.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 56/0.04/0.04 ng/mL, ALT/AST: 16/34 IU/L, Alk Phos/T Bili: 74/1.6 IU/L, Amylase/Lipase: 9/9 IU/L, Differential-Neuts: 88.1%, Lymph: 7.3%, Mono: 3.4%, Eos: 1.0%, Lactic Acid: 2.4 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.4 g/dL, LDH: 267 IU/L, Ca++: 7.1 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.8 mg/dL, PO4: 2.1 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CTA: No evidence of pulmonary embolus, but interval development of widespread patchy ground-glass opacities, which may represent an atypical infection or drug reaction.
* PET scan: Increased mass-like thickening of the distal esophagus compared to the [**Month (only) 319**] PET scan, with minimal interval increase in size of prevascular lymph nodes and gastroesophageal lymph nodes.

The patient's medical history and current condition suggest the following potential medical complications:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's condition is likely due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from peritonitis or pneumonia, hemorrhage, aspiration, or influenza, rather than pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation, or decreased ejection fraction.
2. Hypotension with lactic acidosis: The patient's blood pressure is ranging from 80s to 130s systolic, representing pain and possible underlying sepsis with elevated lactate. The differential diagnosis includes sepsis, hypovolemia, and cardiogenic shock.
3. Low urine output: The patient's urine output is low, likely due to ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely due to underlying sympathetic drive to breathe and pain.
5. Anasarca/liver disease: The patient's anasarca is likely due to liver disease, although cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out.
6. Esophageal cancer: The patient's esophageal cancer is thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and 5-FU.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime, as well as Vanc, Zosyn, and Azithro.
* Monitor ABG and lactate levels.
* Wean from pressors as able to.
* Administer albumin 50g.
* Boluses with fluid when respiratory status improves.
* Repeat EKG and continue Mexilitine.
* Treat liver disease based on recommendations from hepatology.
* Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the oncology team about admission and follow up on any recommendations they may have.
* Continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan as necessary.

   / Lipase:/9, Differential-Neuts:88.1 %, Lymph:7.3 %, Mono:3.4 %,
   Eos:1.0 %, Lactic Acid:2.4 mmol/L, Albumin:2.4 g/dL, LDH:267 IU/L,
   Ca++:7.1 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL  On transfer: Labs
   notable for WBC of 17, lactate of 6.0.
   CTA
   IMPRESSION:
   1. No evidence of pulmonary embolus.
   2. Interval development of widespread patchy ground-glass opacities.
   Given
   the rapidity of onset, this most likely represents an atypical
   infection or
   drug reaction.
   3. Increased mass-like thickening of the distal esophagus compared to
   the
   [**Month (only) 319**] PET scan, with minimal interval increase in size of prevascular
   lymph
   nodes and gastroesophageal lymph nodes. There is ascites and a nodular
   appearance of the mesentery, which may be due to worsening hepatic
   failure,
   but is also concerning for carcinomatosis.
   4. Stable biilateral pleural effusions.
   BAL, Ascites, and Sputum: NTD
   Urine: small amount of probable enterococcus
   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially thought to be PE and patient
   was started on Heparin despite guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent
   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for
   hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Continue broadened coverage to Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime (expanded GI and
   GNR coverage) as well as Vanc, Zosyn, Azithro
   - Q2 MDIs PRN
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves
   .
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs
   they may have
   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, start tube feeds
   #Prophy: pneumoboots, heparin TID, type and screen
   #Code status: Full Code
   #Communication: Patient; brother is health care proxy
   #Dispo: pending clinical stability

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C who was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxia and respiratory failure. He was found to have diffuse ground-glass opacities on CT scan and was intubated. The patient's condition worsened, and he developed pulmonary edema, hypotension, and tachycardia. He was treated with fluid boluses, vasopressors, and antibiotics, and was also given medications for pain and sedation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and hypotension suggest that he may be developing sepsis, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, peritonitis, or aspiration.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's elevated troponin levels and decreased ejection fraction suggest that he may be at risk of developing cardiac failure.
4. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver disease and elevated bilirubin levels suggest that he may be at risk of developing hepatic failure.
5. Anasarca: The patient's fluid overload and edema suggest that he may be at risk of developing anasarca, a condition characterized by widespread edema.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may be at risk of developing an infection.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's elevated lactate levels and hypotension suggest that he may be at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated potassium and magnesium levels suggest that he may be at risk of developing an electrolyte imbalance.
9. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output suggest that he may be at risk of developing renal failure.
10. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's elevated D-dimer levels and hypoxia suggest that he may be at risk of developing a pulmonary embolism.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He was initially suspected to have pulmonary embolism (PE) but was found to have widespread patchy ground-glass opacities on CT scan, consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from peritonitis, pneumonia, hemorrhage, aspiration, or influenza. He was intubated and started on ARDSnet protocol. The patient has a high suspicion of sepsis, with elevated lactate levels, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels, tachycardia, and hypotension suggest sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
2. ARDS: The patient's diffuse ground-glass opacities on CT scan and hypoxic respiratory failure suggest ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
3. Hepatic failure: The patient's history of hepatitis C and elevated liver enzymes suggest potential hepatic failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and death.
4. Cardiac failure: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension suggest potential cardiac failure, which can lead to cardiogenic shock and death.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels suggest potential renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and death.
6. Anasarca: The patient's fluid overload and edema suggest anasarca, which can lead to respiratory compromise and death.
7. Infection: The patient's broad-spectrum antibiotics suggest potential infection, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of esophageal cancer and bleeding from the indwelling port suggest potential gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, lab results, and imaging studies to assess for progression of sepsis, ARDS, and organ dysfunction.
2. Continue to treat the patient with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungals to cover potential infections.
3. Consider adding vasopressors to support blood pressure and cardiac function.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid status and electrolyte levels to prevent fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Consider transferring the patient to a higher-level ICU or a specialty unit for further management of his complex medical condition.

   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was admitted to the ICU for new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient's condition worsened, and he was intubated and put on ARDSnet protocol.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure, ARDS, and pulmonary edema
* Cardiovascular: Hypotension, tachycardia, and lactic acidosis
* Neurological: No neurological deficits reported
* Hematological: Normal WBC count, but elevated lactate
* Gastrointestinal: Malnutrition, liver disease, and anasarca
* Infectious: Possible sepsis, pneumonia, or viral infection

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: Continued hypoxia and pulmonary edema may lead to further deterioration of lung function, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially necessitating extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Cardiovascular instability: Hypotension and lactic acidosis may indicate underlying sepsis, hypovolemia, or cardiogenic shock, which can be challenging to manage and may require vasopressors, inotropes, and fluid resuscitation.
3. Infection: The patient's history of hepatitis C and liver disease increases the risk of sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). Pneumonia, sepsis, and other infections may require broad-spectrum antibiotics and antiviral therapy.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: Malnutrition, liver disease, and anasarca may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction, which can worsen the patient's condition.
5. Neurological deterioration: The patient's tachycardia and lactic acidosis may indicate underlying neurological dysfunction, which can progress to more severe conditions such as encephalopathy or seizures.
6. Hematological complications: The patient's elevated lactate and possible sepsis may lead to further hematological complications, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or thrombocytopenia.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management, including:

* Continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Vasopressors and inotropes to maintain blood pressure and cardiac output
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics and antiviral therapy to cover possible infections
* Gastrointestinal support, including nutrition and electrolyte management
* Neurological monitoring and management, including sedation and analgesia
* Hematological monitoring and management, including platelet and coagulation factor support
* Cardiac monitoring and management, including echocardiography and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels

The patient's code status is Full Code, and his disposition is pending clinical stability.

Based on the patient's 24-hour events, the patient was brought back to the ICU for new-onset hypoxia. The patient was found to have a diffuse ground-glass appearance to the lungs on CT scan, and hypoxia worsened, requiring intubation. A bronchoscopy was performed, which was unrevealing for the cause of the hypoxia other than a small amount of bleeding.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* T-max: 36.7C (98.1F)
* T-current: 36.7C (98F)
* HR: 87 (74-160) bpm
* BP: 89/54 (68) mmHg
* RR: 26 (19-36) inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 98%

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 7.2-13.0 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 27-33.9%
* Plt: 38-71 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 0.7-0.9 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01-0.04 ng/mL
* TCO2: 20-23 mmHg
* Glucose: 104-246 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient is being treated for ARDS, and a bronchoscopy was performed to evaluate for hemorrhage.
* Hypotension with lactic acidosis: The patient's blood pressure is ranging from 80s to 130s systolic, and lactate is elevated due to hypoxia, high work of breathing, and poor liver clearance.
* Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is 160 bpm, likely due to underlying sympathetic drive to breathe and pain.
* Anasarca/liver disease: The patient's liver disease is likely contributing to the anasarca, although some cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out.
* Esophageal CA: The patient's esophageal cancer is thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and 5-FU.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and bronchoscopy may increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate may indicate underlying sepsis.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may be indicative of cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver disease and elevated lactate may increase the risk of liver failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, lab results, and respiratory status. The patient's treatment plan should be adjusted accordingly to address any potential complications that may arise.

   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative,
   rapidly evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from possible pulmonary
   source.
   Initially thought to be PE and patient was started on Heparin despite
   guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent with ARDS from peritonitis or
   PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage, aspiration, or influenza versus
   Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after paracentesis, aggressive
   resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx and recent normal echo.
   Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet protocol.  He had a
   bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin
   because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Broaden coverage to Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  This should cover
   atypicals, gm (+) and gm (-)
   - nebulized treatments q 4 hours
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   - Stat KUB looking for perf d/t recent paracenteses
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves
   .
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine if has dosing for renal failure
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs
   they may have
   - email Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] to see if any of chemo drugs could be contributory

   time.

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure, septic shock, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He has a dilated colon, ascites, and nodular mesentery, suggesting worsening hepatic failure or carcinomatosis. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, pressors, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. He has also undergone a bronchoscopy and is being treated for pain, constipation, and adrenal insufficiency.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment. The broad-spectrum antibiotics and pressors are intended to combat the underlying infection and improve cardiac output.
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is a serious complication that can lead to respiratory failure, multiorgan dysfunction, and mortality. The patient's lungs are being treated with mechanical ventilation and ARDSnet protocol.
3. Hepatic Failure: The patient's ascites and nodular mesentery suggest worsening hepatic failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and death. The patient is being treated with albumin and lactulose to manage the ascites.
4. Constipation: The patient's dilated colon suggests constipation, which can lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, and sepsis. The patient is being treated with laxatives and stool softeners.
5. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency is a potential complication of his underlying disease and treatment. The patient is being treated with hydrocortisone and fluticasone to manage the adrenal insufficiency.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and elevated troponin levels suggest cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction or stress cardiomyopathy. The patient's cardiac enzymes are being monitored, and he is being treated with beta-blockers and vasopressors as needed.
7. Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest renal failure, which can worsen the patient's overall prognosis. The patient is being treated with diuretics and hemodialysis as needed.
8. Infection: The patient's septic shock and ARDS suggest infection, which can lead to multiorgan dysfunction and death. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and he is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to manage his multiple medical complications.

Summary:

The patient, a 58-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, renal failure, and a dilated colon. He has a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C. He is intubated and on multiple pressors, and has been started on a broad-spectrum antibiotic regimen. The patient's condition is complicated by septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), constipation, pleural disease, pain control issues, and ascites.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely due to a pulmonary source, and his respiratory status has improved slightly but remains ventilator-dependent.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's CXRs show worsening bilateral airspace opacities, and his CT scan suggests atypical pneumonia, which is being covered with antibiotics.
3. Constipation: The patient's colonic distension is concerning for obstruction, C. difficile-mediated megacolon, or acute pseudo-obstruction syndrome.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's BAL fluid was inadequate to rule out flu, and he is being treated with oseltamivir and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
5. Liver Disease: The patient's ascites and nodular mesentery are concerning for worsening hepatic failure or carcinomatosis.
6. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient did not respond to a cortisol stim test and is being treated with fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.
7. Anasarca: The patient's fluid overload is likely due to liver disease and malnutrition.
8. Esophageal Cancer: The patient's history of esophageal cancer in remission is a concern, and he should be followed up with his oncologist.

Recommendations:

1. Repeat C. difficile testing and continue treatment with IV Flagyl and PO Vanco.
2. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis.
3. Wean levophed further as tolerated and consider discontinuing pressors.
4. Replete electrolytes PRN and hold tube feeds until the patient's colonic distension improves.
5. Consider non-contrast abdominal CT scan to assess for obstruction or other causes of constipation.
6. Follow up with hepatology and oncology services to manage liver disease and esophageal cancer.
7. Monitor the patient's fluid status and consider diuretic therapy to manage anasarca.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a chief complaint of shock and respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 17.5 K/uL
* Platelet count: 84 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* TCO2: 19 mmHg
* Glucose: 151 mg/dL
* Other lab results are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* Right lower extremity edema: Trace
* Left lower extremity edema: Trace
* Warm skin
* Responds to noxious stimuli
* Non-purposeful movement
* Normal tone

The patient has a history of cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. He is currently receiving treatment for septic shock, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and ARDS.

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning PEEP and FiO2 as tolerated
* Continuing present antibiotics, including oseltamivir
* CT scan today
* Discussing CT results with hepatology and considering colonoscopic decompression or CT
* Continuing steroids for adrenal insufficiency
* Sending peritoneal fluid for cell count
* Weaning pressors as tolerated
* If CVP falls, administering albumin
* Sending rheumatoid factor and cryocrit

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Continued septic shock and organ dysfunction
* Development of acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease
* Respiratory failure and worsening of hypoxemia
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy and platelet count
* Increased risk of infection due to immunosuppression and presence of central lines
* Worsening of liver function and development of liver failure
* Development of adrenal crisis due to inadequate treatment of adrenal insufficiency
* Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to coagulopathy and presence of indwelling lines.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, septic shock, oliguria resolved, cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS can progress to more severe respiratory failure, leading to respiratory arrest or death.
2. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock can worsen, leading to multi-organ failure, including cardiovascular, renal, and hepatic failure.
3. Oliguria: The patient's oliguria can persist, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can worsen, leading to bleeding complications or thrombotic events.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency can worsen, leading to adrenal crisis or death.
6. Infection: The patient's septic shock and respiratory failure can lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's cirrhosis and coagulopathy can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Hepatic failure: The patient's cirrhosis can progress to hepatic failure, leading to liver failure and death.
9. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's septic shock and hypotension can lead to cardiovascular instability, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
10. Neurological complications: The patient's septic shock and hypotension can lead to neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, and brain death.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications. The plan includes weaning PEEP and FiO2, continuing antibiotics, and managing hemodynamic instability. The patient's family members have been informed of his condition and treatment plan.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Continue treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t grim clinical
   scenario
   - NPO for now
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.
   - f/u ID recs.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.
   .

   distension.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C. He has been admitted to the ICU with acute onset respiratory distress, and his condition has rapidly deteriorated over the past 12 hours.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Heart rate: 78 bpm (62-78 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 92/51 mmHg (64-127/84 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute (21-25 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 22 mmHg (10-22 mmHg)

The patient has a distended colon with no evidence of small or large bowel obstruction on CT scan. He has also developed extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan, which are suggestive of atypical pneumonia. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro, and is being covered for flu and bacterial cultures.

The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent on assist control. His lactate has improved to normal range, and he has been able to come off of pressors except for Levophed.

The patient's abdominal distension is concerning for colonic pseudo-obstruction, which is a potential complication of his esophageal cancer and liver disease. He has been treated with IV Flagyl and PO Vanco, and his C. diff test has come back negative.

The patient's laboratory results are:

* WBC: 6.3-5.0 K/uL
* Hct: 24.9-24.4%
* Plt: 33-30 K/uL
* Cr: 0.8-0.7 mg/dL
* TCO2: 19-22 mmHg
* Glucose: 188-132 mg/dL

The patient's imaging results are:

* CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast: distended colon with stool and gas, without wall-thickening, obstruction or pneumatosis
* CXR: diffuse bilateral airspace consolidations
* CT scan with contrast: no evidence of small or large bowel obstruction

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis from pneumonia or other sources
* Respiratory failure from atypical pneumonia or other causes
* Colonic pseudo-obstruction or obstruction
* Hepatic encephalopathy from liver disease
* Adrenal insufficiency from shock or other causes
* Anasarca or edema from liver disease or other causes
* Esophageal cancer recurrence or progression

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue treatment for atypical pneumonia with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary
* Manage respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and other supportive measures
* Continue to monitor for colonic pseudo-obstruction or obstruction and adjust treatment as necessary
* Monitor for signs of adrenal insufficiency and adjust treatment as necessary
* Monitor for signs of anasarca or edema and adjust treatment as necessary
* Continue to monitor for signs of esophageal cancer recurrence or progression and adjust treatment as necessary.

   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Continue treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t grim clinical
   scenario
   - NPO for now
   - decompression with GI today or tomorrow.
   - If decompression does not work, will consider neostigmine
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   - Fix abdominal issues as above.
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today (decided on 75 total)
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.
   .

   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, holding tube feeds because of colonic
   distension.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C. He was admitted to the ICU with acute onset respiratory distress and has been experiencing a range of complications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is ventilator-dependent on assist control and has new, extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia. He is being treated with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro and oseltamivir for possible flu.
* Abdominal: He has a distended colon with stool and gas, and a repeat CT scan with contrast confirmed no anatomic obstruction. He is being treated with IV Flagyl and PO Vanco for possible C. diff-mediated megacolon and acute pseudo-obstruction.
* Cardiovascular: He has hypotension, which appears to be multifactorial from sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, and liver disease. He is being treated with fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency and is being weaned off levophed.
* Renal: His urine output has improved with improving hemodynamics, and his creatinine is stable.
* Hepatic: He has liver disease, which is likely contributing to his anasarca and possible cardiac involvement.
* Hematological: He has a low platelet count, which may be related to his liver disease and chemotherapy.
* Infection: He has a range of infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and possible peritoneal fluid infection.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent. There is a risk of further respiratory decline if his pneumonia is not effectively treated.
* Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver disease may worsen, leading to further complications such as coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and bleeding.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine is stable, but there is a risk of further kidney damage if his blood pressure is not adequately controlled.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to further complications such as cardiac arrest, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's distended colon may lead to further complications such as perforation, peritonitis, and sepsis.
* Hematological complications: The patient's low platelet count may worsen, leading to bleeding complications and increased risk of infection.

In terms of management, the patient's care should focus on:

* Continuing to treat his pneumonia with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro and oseltamivir.
* Managing his abdominal distension with decompression and possible neostigmine.
* Monitoring his hemodynamics and adjusting his vasopressor therapy as needed.
* Managing his electrolyte imbalances and holding tube feeds until his colonic distension is resolved.
* Continuing to monitor his liver function and adjusting his treatment plan accordingly.
* Monitoring his platelet count and adjusting his platelet transfusions as needed.
* Ensuring that his code status is up-to-date and communicating with his brother, who is his healthcare proxy.

The patient is a 58-year-old man admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, septic shock, oliguria, cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. He has received various medications, including antibiotics, steroids, and vasopressors. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 62 bpm, blood pressure of 95/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 410 mL and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His lab results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase, as well as decreased hemoglobin and albumin levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is still at risk for further deterioration. Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to ventilator-associated lung injury and respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not managed promptly and effectively.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can increase his risk of bleeding complications, particularly if he requires invasive procedures or has a traumatic injury.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency requires ongoing steroid replacement therapy to prevent adrenal crisis.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's cirrhosis can lead to liver failure, which can worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of bleeding and infection.
6. Renal failure: The patient's oliguria can progress to acute kidney injury, which can require dialysis and increase his risk of morbidity and mortality.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and his current liver dysfunction can increase his risk of further bleeding complications.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing further infections, particularly pneumonia, given his respiratory failure and immunosuppressed state.
9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's septic shock and hypotension can lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.
10. Neurological complications: The patient's septic shock and hypotension can also lead to neurological complications, such as seizures and altered mental status.

   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - passed RSBI this morning, will trial SBT this morning
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   - Fix abdominal issues as below
   .
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Continue treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t grim clinical
   scenario
   - NPO for now
   - decompression with GI today
   - If decompression does not work, will consider neostigmine
   .
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fludricortisone 0.1 and hydrocortisone  75 for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today (decided on 75 total)
   .
   #Hct drop: Dropped to 21.2 from 24 this morning.  Rechecked 4 hours
   later and was 23.
   - q8 hour crit
   -<21
 transfusion
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   .
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   - Add lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who has developed new hypoxic respiratory failure and is currently in the ICU. The patient's condition is complex, with multiple potential medical complications.

Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent on assist control. He has new, extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which is being covered with antibiotics. The patient's BAL fluid was inadequate to rule out flu, so oseltamivir is being continued for the time being.

Colonic Distension: The patient's abdomen is distended, and a CT scan with contrast confirmed no anatomic obstruction. The differential diagnosis includes obstruction, C. difficile-mediated megacolon, and acute pseudo-obstruction syndrome. The patient is being treated with IV Flagyl and PO Vanco, and a rectal tube has been placed to help decompress the colon.

Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has improved, but he is still requiring pressors. His sepsis is likely coming from his lungs, and he is being treated with antibiotics. The patient did not respond to a cortisol stim test, so he is being given fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.

Hct Drop: The patient's Hct has dropped to 21.2 from 24 this morning, but has since improved to 23. He is being given q8 hour crit and is at risk for bleeding.

Low UOP: The patient's urine output has improved with improving hemodynamics and his creatinine is stable.

Anasarca/Liver Disease: The patient's anasarca is likely due to liver disease, although some cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out.

Esophageal CA: The patient's esophageal cancer is thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and 5-FU.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Colonic distension: The patient's colon is distended, and he is at risk for perforation or bowel obstruction.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial and may worsen if not adequately treated.
4. Hct drop: The patient's Hct drop is concerning and may indicate bleeding or other complications.
5. Low UOP: The patient's low urine output is concerning and may indicate kidney damage or other complications.
6. Anasarca/liver disease: The patient's anasarca and liver disease are concerning and may worsen if not adequately treated.
7. Esophageal CA: The patient's esophageal cancer is a potential source of complications, including bleeding or obstruction.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics for respiratory failure and colonic distension.
2. Continue IV Flagyl and PO Vanco for colonic distension.
3. Wean levophed further as tolerated.
4. Give fludricortisone 0.1 and hydrocortisone 75 for adrenal insufficiency.
5. Albumin 1g/kg today (decided on 75 total).
6. q8 hour crit for Hct drop.
7. Continue lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen.
8. Add pneumoboots for prophylaxis.
9. Monitor patient's respiratory status closely and consider tracheostomy if necessary.
10. Monitor patient's colonic distension closely and consider decompression if necessary.
11. Monitor patient's hypotension closely and consider increasing pressors if necessary.
12. Monitor patient's Hct and UOP closely and consider transfusions or dialysis if necessary.
13. Monitor patient's liver function and consider liver transplant if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, septic shock, cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. He is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and sedation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7C (99.8F)
* Heart rate: 69 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 75/46 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Central venous pressure: 13 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 44 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23 mg/dL
* Sodium: 138 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.0 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 597 IU/L

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* Tidal volume: 410-486 mL
* Respiratory rate: 22-3 breaths per minute
* Positive end-expiratory pressure: 8 cmH2O
* Fraction of inspired oxygen: 50%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Thin
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, diminished distension
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema 1+, Left lower extremity edema 1+
* Neurologic: Unresponsive, no spontaneous movement

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Coagulopathy
* Adrenal insufficiency
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Kidney injury
* Liver failure
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Hypotension
* Hypoxemia
* Pneumonia
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Catheter-related bloodstream infection

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and vasopressor support
* Get another C. difficile test if three negative and negative flex sig, then consider discontinuing antibiotics
* Hold sedation and try spontaneous breathing trials later today
* Follow hemoglobin levels
* Continue present steroids for now
* Check KUB and consider neostigmine if [**Last Name (un) 5975**] recurs
* NPO for today, trial of tube feeding tomorrow, and consider total parenteral nutrition if unsuccessful.

   All BAL, sputum, stool, and blood cultures have been NTD
   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - passed RSBI this morning, will trial SBT this morning
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  NTD
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Cipro.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   - Fix abdominal issues as below
   .
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Stop treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t  3 negative cdiff
   - NPO for now
   - aggressive bowel regimen

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who has been readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent on assist control.

The patient's conditions that require close monitoring and potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he remains ventilator-dependent. There is a risk of further deterioration and potential need for tracheostomy.
2. Colonic distension: The patient's colon is distended, which may lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, or megacolon. The patient's C. difficile test is negative, but the etiology of the colonic distension is unclear.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is still labile, and he requires support with Levophed. There is a risk of further hypotension and potential cardiovascular instability.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol stim test is negative, and he is receiving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency. There is a risk of adrenal crisis if the patient's adrenal function does not improve.
5. Anasarca: The patient has significant edema, which may be related to liver disease, cardiac involvement, or both. There is a risk of further fluid accumulation and potential cardiovascular compromise.
6. Low UOP: The patient's urine output has improved, but it is still low. There is a risk of further decreased urine output and potential renal compromise.
7. Esophageal CA: The patient has a history of esophageal cancer, which has been treated with cisplatin and 5-FU. There is a risk of recurrence or metastasis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 3.7-3.3 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 21.2-23.4%
* Platelet count: 24-24 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9-0.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26-23 mg/dL
* Glucose: 127-161 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 597 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest radiograph: Dense airspace opacity is seen in both lungs, with new obscuration of the right hemidiaphragm, which may represent non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
* CT scan: No anatomic obstruction is seen, but there is evidence of atypical pneumonia.

The patient's medication list includes:

* Vanc/Meropenem/Cipro for septic shock
* Fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
* Albumin for liver disease and anasarca
* Lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen
* Nebulizers and guaifenisen for respiratory support
* Fentanyl and propofol for pain and sedation

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Cipro for septic shock
* Wean Levophed further as tolerated
* Albumin 1g/kg today
* Add lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen
* Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN
* Fix abdominal issues with rectal tube placement and aggressive bowel regimen
* Consider neostigmine for bowel regimen
* Monitor for signs of adrenal crisis and adjust treatment as necessary
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and adjust treatment as necessary
* Monitor for signs of hypotension and adjust treatment as necessary
* Monitor for signs of anasarca and adjust treatment as necessary.

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent.

The patient has several comorbidities, including liver disease, malnutrition, and cancer, which may contribute to his current condition. He has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, meropenem, and ciprofloxacin, for suspected sepsis.

The patient's abdominal issues include colonic distension, which has been partially improved with rectal tube placement. He has been diagnosed with atypical pneumonia, and his respiratory failure is likely secondary to this infection.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 3.7-3.3 K/uL

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he remains ventilator-dependent. He has atypical pneumonia, which may worsen his respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been treated with antibiotics, but he remains septic. He may develop further complications, such as organ failure, if his sepsis is not effectively managed.
3. Abdominal issues: The patient's colonic distension may recur, and he may develop further complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
4. Liver disease: The patient has liver disease, which may worsen his condition. He may develop further complications, such as liver failure or portal hypertension.
5. Malnutrition: The patient is malnourished, which may worsen his condition. He may develop further complications, such as muscle wasting or weakness.
6. Cancer: The patient has a history of esophageal cancer, which may recur or worsen his condition.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue antibiotics as prescribed to manage sepsis.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
3. Continue to manage his abdominal issues, including colonic distension, with rectal tube placement and bowel regimen.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider further treatment for his liver disease.
5. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider further treatment for his malnutrition.
6. Monitor the patient's cancer status and consider further treatment for his esophageal cancer.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who has been readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure.

The patient has undergone several procedures and treatments, including:

1. SBT (Spontaneous Breathing Trial) which was stopped due to tachypnea and agitation, and the patient was reintubated.
2. Colonoscopy with dilated rectum to R colon, no obstruction or volvulus, and was decompressed.
3. KUB (Kidney, Ureter, and Bladder) showing resolution of dilatation of the colon with no evidence of large or small bowel obstruction.
4. Repeat stool cultures showing no C. difficile toxin A & B by EIA.
5. Imaging studies showing dense airspace opacity in both lungs, consistent with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
6. Blood cultures showing probable Enterococcus.
7. Administration of antibiotics (Vanc/Meropenem/Cipro) for septic shock and ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome).
8. Treatment for colonic distension with rectal tube placement, aggressive bowel regimen, and neostigmine.
9. Management of hypotension with levophed and fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.
10. Transfusion of 1g/kg of albumin.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory status: ventilator-dependent on assist control.
* Hemodynamic status: stable, with normal lactate levels.
* Renal function: stable, with no changes in creatinine levels.
* Liver function: likely abnormal, with anasarca and liver disease.
* WBC count: 3.7.
* Hct: 21.2.
* Platelet count: 24.
* Blood cultures: positive for probable Enterococcus.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: continued ventilator dependence, potential for further deterioration.
2. Sepsis: ongoing septic shock, potential for further organ dysfunction.
3. Colonic distension: continued risk of perforation, potential for further complications.
4. Liver disease: ongoing anasarca, potential for further liver dysfunction.
5. Hypotension: ongoing risk of shock, potential for further organ dysfunction.
6. Renal failure: potential for further decline in renal function.
7. Infection: ongoing risk of infection, potential for further complications.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and optimize his clinical status.

   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   - Fix abdominal issues as below
   .
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Continue treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t grim clinical
   scenario
   - NPO for now
   - decompression with GI today
   - If decompression does not work, will consider neostigmine
   .
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fludricortisone 0.1 and hydrocortisone  75 for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today (decided on 75 total)
   .
   #Hct drop: Dropped to 21.2 from 24 this morning.  Rechecked 4 hours
   later and was 23.
   - q8 hour crit
   -<21
 transfusion
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   .
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   - Add lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.
   .
   #Access: L IJ, A line, chemo port and PIV.
   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, holding tube feeds because of colonic
   distension.
   #Prophy: pneumoboots, heparin TID, type and screen; lactulose for bowel
   regimen
   #Code status: Full Code
   #Communication: Patient; brother is health care proxy
   #Dispo: pending clinical stability

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient, a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He has been treated with antibiotics and respiratory support, and his respiratory status has improved slightly. He has also been diagnosed with colonic distension and anasarca, and is being treated with decompression and albumin infusions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has new, extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which may be septic in origin.
3. Sepsis: The patient has been treated for sepsis, but it is unclear whether the source of sepsis is from his lungs or abdomen.
4. Colonic Distension: The patient's colonic distension has improved with decompression, but he is at risk for further complications, including perforation or obstruction.
5. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is likely related to liver disease, but it may also be exacerbated by his malnutrition and cancer.
6. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient has been treated for adrenal insufficiency, but it is unclear whether this is a primary or secondary condition.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial, and he is at risk for further episodes of hypotension.
8. Liver Disease: The patient's liver disease is likely to worsen over time, and he is at risk for complications such as bleeding and encephalopathy.
9. Cancer Recurrence: The patient's esophageal cancer has been in remission, but there is a risk of recurrence.
10. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient is at risk for nutritional deficiencies due to his malnutrition and cancer.

Based on this summary and potential medical complications, it is recommended that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU, with a focus on managing his respiratory status, sepsis, and colonic distension.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79.8 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and shock. The patient has undergone a colonoscopy with decompression, and the C. diff test was negative. The patient is currently receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 123/58 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 3.7 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 24 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and their liver enzymes are mildly elevated.

The patient has a diagnosis of shock, septic, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), constipation, pleural disease, pain control, and ascites. The patient is receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury or liver dysfunction.
2. Prolonged mechanical ventilation, which can lead to ventilator-associated lung injury and prolonged ICU stay.
3. Constipation, which can lead to bowel obstruction or perforation.
4. Pleural disease, which can lead to respiratory compromise or pleural effusion.
5. Pain control issues, which can lead to patient discomfort and agitation.
6. Ascites, which can lead to respiratory compromise or abdominal compartment syndrome.
7. Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia or bloodstream infections.
8. Metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
9. Nutritional deficiencies, such as protein-energy malnutrition.
10. ICU-acquired weakness or muscle wasting.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan as necessary to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, septic shock (resolved), cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency, likely with [**Last Name (un) 5975**] syndrome. The patient has improved substantially with hemodynamic management, steroids, and time.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7C (99.8F)
* Heart rate: 98 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 123/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Thin general appearance
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* Right and left lower extremity edema (1+)
* Unable to stand
* Warm skin
* Responds to noxious stimuli, non-purposeful movement, and normal tone
* PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Normocephalic head, ears, nose, and throat
* Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Breath sounds with crackles

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 3.7 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 21.2%
* Platelet count: 24 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Total bilirubin: 23.4 mol/L
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 597 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl (concentrate) infusion: 50 mcg/hour
* Propofol infusion: 30 mcg/kg/min
* Famotidine (Pepcid): 20 mg orally
* Metronidazole: 500 mg orally
* Ciprofloxacin: 500 mg orally
* Vancomycin: 1 g intravenously
* Meropenem: 1 g intravenously
* Albumin: 25% solution, 50 mL intravenously

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing current antibiotics for at least 7 days if cultures remain negative
* Holding sedation and attempting spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) later today
* Continuing steroids for now, with consideration for weaning soon
* Checking KUB (kidneys, ureters, and bladder) for [**Last Name (un) 5975**] syndrome recurrence
* Discussing with the liver team whether to leave the paracentesis site draining or attempt closure
* Providing tube feeds
* Giving albumin for ongoing auto-paracentesis through the IR paracentesis site

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure/ARDS progression
* Sepsis recurrence
* Coagulopathy worsening
* Adrenal insufficiency worsening
* [**Last Name (un) 5975**] syndrome recurrence
* Infection due to indwelling lines or catheters
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to coagulopathy or cirrhosis
* Electrolyte imbalance due to albumin administration
* Fluid overload due to ongoing auto-paracentesis
